title-group.article-title: Evaluation of diagnostic value and Mendelian randomization study of appendicitis hub genes obtained by WGCNA analysis

contrib-group.aff: aDepartment of Gastrointestinal Surgery, The First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing, China.

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence: Wei Zhang, Department of Gastrointestinal Surgery, The First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing 400016, China (e-mail: cyzhangwei@hotmail.com).

The work cannot be used commercially without permission from the journal.

abstract.p: The timely and precise diagnosis of appendicitis was deemed essential. This study sought to examine the diagnostic significance of hub genes linked to appendicitis and to delve deeper into the pathophysiology of the condition. Differential gene expression analysis revealed distinct genes in the appendicitis group compared to other abdominal pain group, while weighted gene co-expression network analysis identified appendicitis-associated modules. Further analysis of common genes was conducted using Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes and Gene Ontology analysis. The diagnostic efficiency of hub genes was explored through the use of nomograms and receiver operator characteristic curves. Additionally, immunoinfiltration analysis was performed to investigate the immune cell infiltration in both groups. The causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis, as well as gut microbiota and appendicitis, was ultimately examined through Mendelian randomization. By conducting differential expression analysis and weighted gene co-expression network analysis, a total of 757 common genes were identified. Subsequent Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes and Gene Ontology enrichment analyses revealed that these common genes were primarily associated with positive regulation of cell adhesion, focal adhesion, protein serine kinase activity, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Utilizing Cytoscape software, the top 10 genes with the highest degree of interaction were identified as RPS3A, RPSA, RPL5, RPL37A, RPS27L, FLT3LG, ARL6IP1, RPL32, MRPL3, and GSPT1. Evaluation using nomograms and receiver operator characteristic curves demonstrated the diagnostic value of these hub genes. Ultimately, a causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis was not identified in our study. Nevertheless, our findings indicate that appendicitis is correlated with 9 gut microbiota. This study identified 5 hub genes, specifically HSP90AA1, RPL5, MYC, CD44, and RPS3A, which exhibit diagnostic significance of appendicitis. Furthermore, the elucidation of these hub genes aids in enhancing our comprehension of the molecular pathways implicated in the development of appendicitis.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The primary presenting symptom of abdominal pain constituted 5% to 10% of all cases seen in the emergency department (ED).[1] Appendicitis emerged as a prevalent general surgical emergency on a global scale, with a reported lifetime risk estimated at 7% to 8%. Typically, the highest incidence of this condition was observed in individuals in their second or third decade of life, with lower occurrences at both ends of the age spectrum.[2,3] Consequently, the prompt and precise identification of appendicitis was deemed essential.

Computed tomography (CT) is currently considered the most widely utilized diagnostic modality for appendicitis. In the United States, approximately 86% of patients with suspected appendicitis undergo preoperative CT scans, with 92.3% of patients ultimately demonstrating congruent postoperative pathology and CT findings.[4–6] However, concerns regarding radiation exposure in pediatric and adolescent populations have prompted consideration of transabdominal ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as alternative diagnostic tools for appendicitis.[7] Transabdominal ultrasound was found to be less accurate than CT due to its increased operator requirements.[8] D’Souza et al[9] demonstrated that MRI was a highly accurate method for diagnosing and ruling out appendicitis. Nevertheless, limited research has been conducted on the use of MRI in diagnosing acute abdominal conditions, leaving the role of MRI in diagnosing appendicitis uncertain.

Distinct symptoms present at the initiation of appendicitis have proven to be valuable in the clinical determination of the condition. While the Alvarado score[10] has been recognized as the predominant scale for this purpose, its clinical utility is hindered by its relatively low specificity. In recent times, various biomarkers, including white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, and bilirubin, have been utilized for the diagnosis of appendicitis.[11–13] Although these markers may aid in the diagnostic process, their effectiveness is constrained by their lack of specificity.

Despite the various diagnostic methods available for appendicitis, a minority of patients underwent unnecessary appendectomies due to misdiagnosis, resulting in a condition known as “negative appendicitis.”[14,15]

In recent years, multiple studies have investigated the biomarkers of appendicitis through the utilization of bioinformatics tools[16,17]; however, there is a notable absence of research on the hub genes associated with this condition. The identification of disease-specific genes has the potential to enhance our comprehension of the molecular mechanisms underlying appendicitis and facilitate the discovery of biomarkers. Various bioinformatics software and databases currently available can aid in the identification of disease-related pathways, including weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WCGNA), Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG), Gene Ontology (GO), and gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA).[18] The WGCNA has seen a rise in utilization for biomarker screening.

Mendelian randomization (MR) is a method employed to evaluate causality between exposure and outcome by utilizing single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) as instrumental variables (IVs). MR has been extensively employed to investigate causal associations between disease and exposure factors.[19,20]

This study utilized a combination of bioinformatics approaches to identify hub genes associated with appendicitis, with the aim of elucidating the molecular mechanisms of the disease and identifying potential biomarkers for its diagnosis. The findings suggest that hub genes could be valuable biomarkers for diagnosing appendicitis, particularly in cases where CT imaging is not readily available or when diagnosis is challenging. Additionally, a MR analysis was conducted to explore the causal relationships between hub genes, gut microbiota, and appendicitis.

sec.title: 2.1. Data source
sec.p: In this study, the dataset, named GSE83091 (Platforms: GPL10558 Illumina HumanHT-12 V4.0 expression beadchip), was downloaded from the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/). There were a total of 40 patients in this dataset, including 20 patients with confirmed appendicitis and 20 patients with other abdominal diseases.

sec.title: 2.2. Identification of differentially expressed genes (DEGs)
sec.p: Initially, the dataset was read and preprocessed utilizing R software (Version 4.3.2), followed by the execution of differential gene expression analysis between the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group using the “limma” package[21] within R software. DEGs were defined based on the criteria of |LogFC| > 1 and adjusted P < .05. Subsequently, the “pheatmap” and “ggplot2” R packages were employed to create a volcano map and a heat map.

sec.title: 2.3. Weighted gene co-expression network analysis
sec.p: The utilization of WGCNA has become more prevalent in the bioinformatics field. WGCNA has been instrumental in identifying significant gene modules and summarizing them through the identification of hub genes. This has greatly enhanced the process of gene screening for improved biomarker identification.[22] In this study, we employed the “WGCNA” packages to conduct WGCNA on appendicitis, resulting in the identification of characteristic gene modules associated with pathogenic mechanisms. Subsequently, the most pertinent module was selected for further analysis.

sec.title: 2.4. Venn diagram and KEGG/GO analysis
sec.p: A Venn diagram was constructed to identify common genes between DEGs and module genes with the highest correlation, which were considered as potential hub genes implicated in the pathogenesis of appendicitis. GO and KEGG databases were utilized for systematic analysis of gene function, with GO analysis results categorized into biological process (BP), cellular component (CC), and molecular function (MF). The “clusterProfiler” R package was employed for KEGG and GO analysis of the common genes to further investigate the underlying biological processes and pathogenesis.[23]

sec.title: 2.5. Protein–protein interaction (PPI) network
sec.p: We obtained the PPI network using the STRING (https://cn.string-db.org/) platform. The PPI network of the top 10 important genes was obtained using the CytoHubba plug-in in the Cytoscape software (Version 3.10.1).

sec.title: 2.6. Nomogram and receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve
sec.p: A nomogram was developed utilizing the “rms” R package to forecast the likelihood of appendicitis.[24] Subsequently, a ROC curve was generated using the “ROC” R package to evaluate the efficacy of potential biomarkers. The area under the curve (AUC) served as a metric for assessment, with a value ranging between 0.9 and 1 indicating heightened accuracy of the biomarker.

sec.title: 2.7. Analysis of immune cells
sec.p: Appendicitis was an infectious disease, and the associated immune cells played a large role in the progression of the disease. We used CIBERSOPT to analyze the immune infiltration of immune cells in the appendicitis group.[25]

sec.title: 2.8. Mendelian randomization
sec.p: We performed the 2-sample MR analysis to explore the causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis, as well as gut microbiota and appendicitis. All data for this study were obtained from open databases. Hub gene data and gut microbiota obtained from the publicly available Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) data source. First, we performed MR analysis of the hub genes and appendicitis. Then we did MR analysis of gut microbiota and appendicitis. The data for gut microbiota were from this link: https://gwas.mrcieu.ac.uk/datasets/ (Accession No. ebi-a-GCST90016908 to ebi-a-GCST90017118), and the data on hub gene and appendicitis were from https://gwas.mrcieu.ac.uk/datasets/. We used the “TwoSampleMR” package for MR analysis, and the inverse variance weighting (IVW) was the primary method to assess causality. MR-Egger, weighted median, simple mode, and weighted were complementary methods to assess causality.

sec.title: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Student t test was used to compare continuous variables, and the chi-square test was used to compare categorical variables. P < .05 was considered a statistical significance. All statistical outcomes were performed by R software (Version 4.3.2).

sec.title: 3.1. DEGs analysis
sec.p: The flowchart of this study was shown in Supplementary Fig. S1, Supplemental Digital Content, http://links.lww.com/MD/N390. The appendicitis dataset (GSE83091) was acquired from the GEO database for the purpose of conducting a differential gene expression analysis. A total of 839 DEGs were identified, consisting of 228 downregulated genes and 611 upregulated genes (Fig. 1A). The heat map visually represented the differential expression patterns of these DEGs between the appendicitis group and a group with other abdominal diseases (Fig. 1B and Supplementary Table S1, Supplemental Digital Content, http://links.lww.com/MD/N388).

caption.p: Genes differentially expressed between the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group. (A) Volcanic map for differential expression analysis. (B) Heat map for differential expression analysis. Blue represents downregulated genes, yellow represents upregulated genes, and black represents undifferentiated genes. A = appendicitis, O = other abdominal disease.

sec.title: 3.2. Construction of WGCNA and identification of appendicitis-related module
sec.p: WGCNA analysis was conducted on all candidate genes in the dataset GSE83091, resulting in the identification of appendicitis-related gene modules. The cluster dendrogram was depicted in Figure 2A, with 4 distinct modules identified as shown in Figure 2B. The MEblue module exhibited a significant correlation (P < .05) with the appendicitis group based on correlation coefficients of different modules, as illustrated in Figure 2C. The genes in the MEblue module are shown in Supplementary Table S2, Supplemental Digital Content, http://links.lww.com/MD/N389.

caption.p: Identification of appendicitis-associated gene modules using WGCNA. (A) Cluster dendrogram of WGCNA. Each branch of a clustered tree represented a gene, while co-expressed modules have different colors to represent. (B) The clustered modules of WGCNA. (C) The blue module’s scatter plot has the highest correlation with appendicitis. WGCNA = weighted gene co-expression network analysis.

sec.title: 3.3. Venn diagram and function enrichment analysis
sec.p: We made a Venn diagram for the genes of the MEblue module and DEGs (Fig. 3A), and a total of 757 common genes were screened as potential hub genes in the pathogenesis of appendicitis. GO and KEGG analyses were performed on 757 genes to further study the underlying biological processes and signaling pathways. The Go analysis included 3 categories (Fig. 3B). The BP analysis showed that positive regulation of cell adhesion, positive regulation of cytokine production, and cellular response to abiotic stimulus were significantly enriched. As for the CC analysis, focal adhesion and cell–substrate junction showed significant enrichment. Protein serine kinase activity and ubiquitin protein ligase binding were the top 2 in the MF analysis. KEGG analysis showed that the common genes mainly affect amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, shigellosis, and prion disease (Fig. 3C).

caption.p: Venn diagram and function enrichment analysis. (A) The Veen plot showed 757 common genes between DEGs and MEblue module. (B) The KEGG enrichment analysis of common genes. (C) The GO enrichment analysis of common genes. DEGs = differentially expressed genes, GO = Gene Ontology, KEGG = Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes.

sec.title: 3.4. PPI network analysis
sec.p: The PPI network of common genes was constructed through the STRING platform (Fig. 4A). Then we used Cytoscape software to screen out the top 10 genes with the degree of interaction, which were RPS3A, RPSA, RPL5, RPL37A, RPS27L, FLT3LG, ARL6IP1, RPL32, MRPL3, and GSPT1 (Fig. 4B).

caption.p: The construction of PPI network. (A) PPI network of common genes. (B) The top 10 genes with the highest degree of interaction. PPI = protein–protein interaction.

sec.title: 3.5. Nomogram and ROC curve
sec.p: We constructed a nomogram (Fig. 5A) and a ROC curve for the top 5 hub genes (HSP90AA1, RPL5, MYC, CD44, RPS3A) to evaluate the diagnostic effect (Fig. 5B). The AUC was used as an evaluation index for the diagnostic effect. The AUC of HSP90AA1, RPL5, MYC, CD44, and RPS3A were 0.995, 0.887, 0.932, 0.930, and 0.910, respectively.

caption.p: Assessment of diagnostic efficacy of hub genes. (A) Nomogram model of hub genes. (B) ROC curves of hub genes. ROC = receiver operator characteristic.

sec.title: 3.6. Immune infiltration analysis
sec.p: By using CIBERSOPT, we performed immune infiltration analysis in the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group to further explore the infiltration of immune cells between the 2 groups. The heat map of the immunoinfiltration analysis was shown in Figure 6A. We found that the infiltration levels of native CD4 T cells and regulatory T cells were significantly higher in the appendicitis group compared with other abdominal disease group, while the infiltration levels of CD4 resting memory T cells and CD4 memory activated T cells were significantly lower in the appendicitis group compared with other abdominal disease group (Fig. 6B).

caption.p: Immunoinfiltration analysis results. (A) Relative distribution of 22 kinds of immune cells between the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group. (B) The difference of immune cell infiltration between the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group. A = appendicitis, OAD = other abdominal disease.

sec.title: 3.7. Exploring causal relationship for appendicitis by MR analysis
sec.p: Ultimately, the causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis was assessed through a 2-sample MR analysis. No significant evidence supporting a causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis was found. Further information is presented in Figure 7A.

caption.p: Mendelian randomization study results. (A) MR analysis of the hub genes and appendicitis. (B) MR analysis of gut microbiota and appendicitis. MR = Mendelian randomization.

sec.p: We conducted a comprehensive analysis of the association between appendicitis and gut microbiota. Our findings indicate that family Acidaminococcaceae (IVW method: OR = 0.734, 95% CI = 0.569–0.946, P = .734), family Bacteroidales (MR-Egger method: OR = 3.070, 95% CI = 1.272–7.414, P = .047), genus Eisenbergiella (IVW method: OR = 0.858, 95% CI = 0.740–0.994, P = .042), genus Eubacterium (MR-Egger method: OR = 0.040, 95% CI = 0.180–0.807, P = .040), genus Lachnospiraceae (IVW method: OR = 1.324, 95% CI = 1.090–1.608, P = .005), genus Parabacteroides (MR-Egger method: OR = 0.216, 95% CI = 0.086–0.547, P = .032), genus Prevotella9 (MR-Egger method: OR = 1.850, 95% CI = 1.178–2.908, P = .019), genus Ruminococcaceae (MR-Egger method: OR = 2.415, 95% CI = 1.188–4.906, P = .035), and genus Turicibacter (IVW method: OR = 1.227, 95% CI = 1.006–1.496, P = .043) exhibit a causal relationship with appendicitis, as illustrated in Figure 7B.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: Appendicitis was the most common pointer for emergency surgery, the most common nonobstetric emergency surgery pointer for pregnant women, and the most common emergency surgery pointer for children.[26–28] Currently, the diagnosis of appendicitis primarily depends on imaging modalities such as ultrasonography, CT, and MRI, each with its own set of advantages and disadvantages. Ultrasonography offers the benefit of no radiation exposure but requires skilled operators, while CT provides superior sensitivity and specificity at the cost of radiation exposure, and MRI, although radiation-free, is associated with higher expenses.[29] Numerous studies have suggested various markers for diagnosing appendicitis, yet the World Society of Emergency Surgery Jerusalem Guidelines[30] for Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Appendicitis do not endorse any specific markers for this purpose. The identification of a biomarker with high diagnostic accuracy is crucial for improving the diagnosis of appendicitis.

In this research, DEGs were identified in the appendicitis group and other abdominal disease group. Subsequently, key module genes were determined through WGCNA. Through multiple bioinformatics analyses of common genes, 5 hub genes were identified, namely HSP90AA1, RPL5, MYC, CD44, and RPS3A. Finally, the causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis, as well as between gut microbiota and appendicitis, was examined using 2-sample MR.

The MYC gene was a proto-oncogene and encoded a nuclear phosphoprotein that played a role in cell cycle progression, apoptosis, and cellular transformation. Previous studies have linked the MYC gene to Burkitt lymphoma.[31] The appendix, characterized as a peripheral lymphatic organ, harbors a significant amount of lymphatic tissue. During the initial phases of appendicitis, the lymphoid tissue undergoes reactive hyperplasia due to bacterial stimulation within the appendix, resulting in the obstruction of the appendiceal cavity. The occlusion of the appendiceal lumen is identified as a prevalent physiological mechanism in the onset of acute appendicitis.[32] Additionally, research has indicated instances of Burkitt lymphoma presenting with appendicitis as an initial symptom.[33,34] Therefore, it is plausible that the MYC gene contributes to the development of appendicitis through its regulation of the lymphoid tissue within the appendix.

The protein encoded by the CD44 gene was a cell-surface glycoprotein involved in cell–cell interactions, cell adhesion, and migration.[35] CD44 primarily mediated such interactions as adhesion and migration of the intestinal endothelium and circulating T lymphocytes.[36] This was consistent with our finding that the levels of infiltrate of both native CD4T cells and regulatory T cells in the immune infiltrate analysis were higher in the appendicitis group. Paajanen et al[37] found that the concentration of CD44 did not differ between the normal group and the appendicitis group, and that CD44 had no significance for the diagnosis of appendicitis. However, Dimberg et al[38] found a strong association between CD44 and the severity of appendicitis. In this study, we found that CD44 serves as a biomarker for appendicitis, and we speculate that CD44 influenced the pathogenesis of appendicitis by mediating the invasion and infiltration of T lymphocytes.

Ribosomes, the organelles that catalyzed protein synthesis, consist of a small 40S subunit and a large 60S subunit. Together these subunits were composed of 4 RNA species and approximately 80 structurally distinct proteins.[39] Both Ribosomal Protein L5 (RPL5) and Ribosomal Protein S3A (RPS3A) are classified as ribosomal protein-related genes. The PPI network analysis revealed the presence of multiple ribosomal protein-related genes. Specifically, the RPL5 gene encodes a member of the L18P family of ribosomal proteins and is a constituent of the 60S subunit, while the RPS3A gene encodes a ribosomal protein that is a constituent of the 40S subunit. Ribosomal proteins serve various functions, with RPL5 being implicated in promoting colon cell proliferation and migration, as well as exhibiting inhibitory effects on breast cancer.[40,41] RPS3A has been identified as a potential therapeutic target in hepatocellular carcinoma and has been shown to have a regulatory impact on coronary artery disease.[42,43] Chawla et al[16] observed that alterations in ribosome proteins during appendicitis were a controlled phenomenon, with the expression patterns of chemokines, defensins, stress-related proteins, and ribosome processing proteins aligning with the immunological processes of the appendiceal immune system. Nevertheless, the specific role of RPL5 and RPS3A in the pathogenesis of appendicitis remains ambiguous.

The protein encoded by the Heat Shock Protein 90 Alpha Family Class A Member 1 (HSP90AA1) gene was an inducible molecular chaperone that functions as a homodimer. The encoded protein aided in the proper folding of specific target proteins by using an ATPase activity that was modulated by co-chaperones.[44] Subsequent research has demonstrated that HSP90AA1 participates in the inflammatory response by acting as a receptor for pathogens.[45–47] In a study by Hu et al,[48] it was observed that HSP90AA1 interacts with avibirnavirus VP2, leading to the induction of autophagy through the inhibition of the AKT-MTOR pathway. Autophagy, in turn, promotes inflammation by modulating NF-κB pathways.[49] Consequently, HSP90AA1 may be a significant contributor to the inflammatory mechanisms associated with appendicitis through its role in autophagy induction.

Ergul[50] observed a higher incidence of appendicitis among patients with a familial history of the condition, suggesting a potential genetic predisposition. Despite this finding, specific appendicitis-related genes have yet to be identified, and a definitive causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis remains elusive. And we did not find a causal relationship between hub genes and appendicitis.

Various pathogens have been identified as closely linked to the pathogenesis of appendicitis.[51,52] The human gut microbiota, comprising a diverse array of bacteria, fungi, and viruses within the intestinal tract, not only directly influences human health but also plays a crucial role in the development of various diseases.[53] In the early stage of acute appendicitis, usually due to the blockage of the appendix cavity, the appendix is ischemic. At this time, the gut microbiota in the appendix cavity begin to multiply, which aggravates the inflammatory reaction in the appendix, leading to the occurrence of appendicitis.[54] The etiology and pathogenesis of appendicitis can be further explored by MR analysis between gut microbiota and appendicitis. Ultimately, we found that family Acidaminococcaceae, genus Eisenbergiella, genus Eubacterium xylanophilum, and genus Parabacteroides were protective factors for appendicitis. And family Bacteroidales, genus Lachnospiraceae, genus Prevotella9, genus Ruminococcaceae, and genus Turicibacter were risk factors for appendicitis.

This study represents a novel contribution to the field as it is the first to utilize WGCNA to identify hub genes associated with appendicitis and to investigate their diagnostic utility. Additionally, the study conducted MR analyses to explore potential causal relationships between hub genes, appendicitis, and gut microbiota. The findings suggest that 9 gut microbiota factors may be causally linked to appendicitis. MR analysis, akin to randomized controlled trials but with reduced systemic bias, was used to strengthen the validity of the results. The stability of the findings was further confirmed through subsequent MR-Egger regression testing.

Nevertheless, it is important to acknowledge the limitations of this study. First, due to the scarcity of available data sets pertaining to appendicitis, only one data set was utilized, potentially introducing selection bias. Including additional data sets could enhance the accuracy of the study findings. Second, the identification of hub genes associated with appendicitis was solely based on bioinformatic methods in the current study, necessitating validation through subsequent biological experiments.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: This study identified 5 hub genes, specifically HSP90AA1, RPL5, MYC, CD44, and RPS3A, which exhibit diagnostic significance of appendicitis. Furthermore, the elucidation of these hub genes aids in enhancing our comprehension of the molecular pathways implicated in the development of appendicitis.

sec.p: We acknowledged all the authors in this article.
